JSRDotNETSDK Reference

SettingAttributes Fields

SettingAttributes Class  See Also

The following tables list the members exposed by the SettingAttributes type.

Fields
Name Description
BOTH_SUPPORTED Sometimes an instrument can support both direct and indexed access. The most common example is gain. The user could pulser.Gain = -13.0, or pulser.GainIndex = 0 to set the gain to the minimum.
DIRECT_SUPPORTED Any setting which is not indexed is a direct property. (and some are both) Here the value is set directly, such as by assigning a value to IPulserReceiver.Gain = 10.0;
FACTORY Factory properties cannot be written to after leaving the factory.
FIXED A fixed setting will never change its value. It is also always readonly. Since a fixed setting is unlikely to be indexed, this attribute is very likely to also have the DIRECT_SUPPORTED attribute below. See RO_FIXED_DIRECT below.
INDEX_SUPPORTED And indexed setting means that the property is controlled by reading and writing an integer index, rather than the value itself. For example the DPR300 has 16 possible PRF rates. So the property PulseRepetitionFrequencyIndex is an integer property that chooses which of the 16 possible rates to use by write a value between 0 and 15. The actual PRF value is accessed by PulseRepetitionFrequencyValues, which is an array of 16 doubles.
NONE Default of zero same as unsupported.
READONLY A setting may be readonly. Obviously things like the Id with the model and serial number would be readonly and fixed. A setting like PowerLimitStatus would be readonly, but wouldn't be fixed, since it can still change its value.
RO_FIXED_DIRECT Probably all pulser settings that are fixed will be direct ones, since there is not much point to being indexed in that case.
SUPPORTED This instrument has this feature, although it might be read-only or fixed at one value.
UNSUPPORTED Unsupported means the hardware doesn't have this feature. Writing or reading the related property will do nothing, and if a value is returned (As opposed to throwing an exception), it will be meaningless. For example, if LEDBlinkRateSupported == UNSUPPORTED, then the device might not have any LED on it. Writing to LEDBlinkRate may generate an exception. Alternatively, a device may not have a feature that is a real setting, but the setting might be supported as a FIXED/READONLY setting, which means writing to it will be ignored or an exception generated. However you can read the value. For example, a DPR300 does not have a way to disable the HV Supply. However, it is always enabled, so the property is supported as a fixed readonly setting that always reports that the HV Supply is enabled. Reading it may also, or may return a value which has no meaning.
VOLATILE Some pulser settings are volatile like PulserLimitStatus which may change even though they are readonly.
Top
